reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s treatment of “memetically potent ideas” as just one blocker, arguing instead that adversarial memetic warfare could dominate and undermine both post-AGI reflection (2.3.1) and trade/compromise (3.x). If true, this would substantially reduce the essay’s optimism about reaching mostly-great futures via deliberation or moral trade, though it wouldn’t strictly refute the essay’s more cautious bottom-line (which already emphasizes blockers and pessimism about WAM-convergence). The argument is conceptually plausible but largely speculative and asserted rather than supported: it doesn’t establish that publishing the concept meaningfully increases risk, nor that such memes can be reliably engineered to ‘disable reflection’ or make threat equilibria ‘inevitable.’ Still, it’s fairly coherent and focused, with little extraneous content.
title: Memetic hazard analysis could become a blueprint for weaponized ideology
